attributes.title: Stick(er)in’ It to the Voter: SMS text voter mobilization and anticipatory benefits

q1.value: Stick(er)in’ It to the Voter: SMS text voter mobilization and anticipatory benefits

q2.value: Christopher Mann | Katherine Haenschen | Hannah Fishman

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This field experiment examines SMS text messages as a method of voter mobilization. The experiment tests how different variations of text messages sent to registered voters encouraging voting can increase voter turnout in the 2018 midterm elections. Despite widespread use, SMS messages have received little scholarly attention as a medium for campaign communication (Dale and Strauss 2009; Malhotra et al 2011; Bhatti et al 2017b). This experiment is part of a series of experiments in the 2018 general election to build on this prior research. The experiment compares two treatments and an uncontacted control group. The Information treatment relies on positive descriptive norms, civic duty and information about voting to increase turnout. These tactics are very common in voter mobilization and have been successful in past randomized controlled tests (see Green and Gerber 2015 for review). The Anticipatory Benefits treatment prompted the voter to look forward to posting on social media to let her friends know she voted. With the anticipatory benefits treatment, the voter was sent a link that lets her share a digital “I Voted” sticker on social media to show her social media friends she is a good citizen because she voted. The experiment is conducted in multiple states covering a range of electoral contexts (defined by competitiveness, voting procedures, and other characteristics). In three states, the treatments were targeted at both early in person voting (EIPV) and Election Day voting (EDay voting): Indiana, Georgia, and New Mexico. In three states, the treatments targeted only Election Day voting: Maryland, Missouri, and Pennsylvania. In the states with EIPV and EDay voting, the experiment addresses a secondary research question about mobilization for these two types of in-person voting: is it more effective to mobilize voters to vote early, to vote on Election Day, or to mobilize for early voting and then for Election Day voting? To the best of our knowledge, this question has received almost no attention despite the widespread availability of early in person voting (cf. Mann and Mayhew 2012). Therefore, treatment records in these states are assigned to mobilization for EIPV only (20%), Election Day only (20%), or both (60%)

registration_responses.q2: Christopher Mann | Katherine Haenschen | Hannah Fishman
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

Therefore, treatment records in these states are assigned to mobilization for EIPV only (20%), Election Day only (20%), or both (60%)

attributes.title: Prevalence and Correlates of Postpartum Depression in sub-Saharan Africa: A Meta-analysis

q1.value: Prevalence and Correlates of Postpartum Depression in sub-Saharan Africa: A Meta-analysis

q2.value: Martins C Nweke, Elizabeth Nseka, Ada C Adiuku-Brown

q3.value:
Postpartum depression (PPD) constitutes a public health problem in resource-constrained sub-Saharan Africa. Efforts directed towards curbing this menace is limited by the wide variability in the reported prevalence and putative correlates of PPD in the region. 
Objective: To synthesize pooled prevalence and correlates of PPD in sub-Saharan Africa. 
Eligibility: Epidemiological studies reporting prevalence and/or correlates of PPD in sub-Saharan Africa. Only articles written and published in English will be included in the review.
Sources of information: Searches will be undertaken of PubMed, MEDLINE, CINAHL, Academic Search Complete, PsycINFO and African Journal Online using piloted and refined search strategy (Appendix 1). Further search of references lists of relevant articles will be undertaken to identify articles for inclusion in the review. 
Data synthesis and assessment of heterogeneity: First, in attempt to answer the questions, “what is the prevalence of PPD in sub-Saharan Africa?” and “what are the correlates of PPD in sub-Saharan Africa?”, we will employ narrative synthesis in which all the articles will be presented, compared and pooled in an evidence table. Furthermore, random-effect model will be fitted to estimate the overall/pooled prevalence and correlates of PPD in sub-Saharan Africa. To assess heterogeneity in the meta-analyses, we will compute the tau-squared (┬2) and the ratio of true heterogeneity to total variation in observed effect (I2).
Data analysis: Meta-analysis of prevalence and correlation coefficients using RevMan 5.3 and MedCalc respectively will be undertaken.  For each, the Cochrane’s Q statistics, I2 and funnel plot will be generated to assess heterogeneity and publication bias across the included studies. α will be set at 0.05.
Result and Discussion: The result of the study promises to provide policy makers and other relevant stakeholders of maternal and child health circle in the region with reliable facts and figures, which will be instrumental to immediate clinical management of PPD as well as strategic planning towards early detection and prevention of PPD in the region, in the coming days.

q4.value: The prevalence and correlates of PPD vary significantly from country to country within the sub-Saharan Africa

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data Item
Data will be collected from variables including authors’ references, participants’ characteristics, inclusion criteria, exclusion criteria, study sample size (also the sample size of groups, where available), method  of assessment, instrument used, the assessor’s occupation, qualification and experience, results, conclusions and funding sources (where applicable).
Quality appraisal and risk of bias assessment 
Quality appraisal will be executed with the aid of the Downs and Black checklist (Downs and Black, 1998). It examines the appropriateness and adequacy methodology, study design, participant recruitment, data collection, data analysis and presentation of findings. It is suitable for appraising most study designs. The tool contains 28 items/questions with a summary score. Ten items focus on the overall quality of the study, 3 items examine the external validity of the study, 7 items concern study bias, six items focus on confounding and selection bias while one item addresses power of the study. Overall, studies will be rated on a four-point Likert scale as follows: excellent (26-28); good (20-25); fair (15-19); and poor (less than or equal to 14) (Hooper et al. 2008). Studies will be judged unclear where information is inadequate to inform judgment regarding risk of bias. However, in such situation, the study authors will be contacted via mail to supply the required information. Non-response from authors will result in exclusion. Reviewer two and three will make independent judgment regarding the risk of bias in consultation with the primary reviewer.

q13.value: As many articles as meet the stipulated eligibility criteria

question.value:
Data analysis
Overall, pooled prevalence will be estimated following Wang and Liu (2016). One way analysis of variance will be used to test the effect of variability in outcome instrument and assessor on prevalence of PPD. Meta-analysis of correlation coefficients will be done through random effect model. To substantiate synthesized evidence, power for the meta-analysis will be computed and reported. RevMan 5 and MedCalc will be used, with α will be set at 0.05.

q25.value:
Information sources and search strategy
Searches will be undertaken using several combinations of search terms from medical subject headings (MeSH), and keywords in the title, abstract and/or text of the articles. First, a PubMed pilot search was conducted to establish a face sensitivity of the search strategy. PubMed pilot search involved search using various MeSH terms and keywords/free text terms generated from articles that are key to the research question. The primary reviewer undertook the pilot search using several combinations of the search terms. The most sensitive and specific terms were chosen and reported in appendix 1. The Terms will be adapted to the syntax and subject headings of the remaining databases. Finally, searches will be undertaken of the following databases: PubMed, MEDLINE, AJOL, Academic Search Complete, CINAHL and PsycINFO. Further search for relevant studies in the references of identified observational and review articles will be performed. Search will be undertaken by the primary reviewer who is a clinical trialist and methodologist. 

Study records and data management
Result of literature search will be exported into EndNote 8, to check for duplication of studies. Bibliographic records will be exported from EndNote 8 into Microsoft Excel version 10 to facilitate data management and selection of articles for inclusion. Eligibility questions and forms for screening of the studies to be included will be developed, piloted and refined.

Selection process
Initial screening will be conducted simultaneously on the title and abstract by two independent reviewers (reviewers 1 and 2). Areas of conflict will be resolved in consultation with a third reviewer author. Critical crosschecking of results of the initial screening, reading through the full text of the selected studies for further screening using the prior outlined eligibility criteria will also be done by the primary reviewer. Authors of selected study will be contacted via mail to clarify issues on selection of any study when decision is difficult to make based on available information. Non-response from any author will result in exclusion of such study and reason for exclusion will be recorded. Details of the flow of studies throughout the selection process will be presented along the reason for exclusion using PRISMA diagram.

Data synthesis and assessment of heterogeneity
The question of what is the prevalence and correlates of PPD in Sub-Saharan Africa will be answered by narrative using an evidence table. Random-effect model of meta-analysis will be employed to estimate the pooled prevalence (DerSimonian and Laird, 1986; Wang and Liu, 2016). Narrative display of measures of heterogeneity i.e. study characteristics will be sorted by year of publication, and presented in an evidence table. This will provide information on author’s references, sample size, study design, setting, outcome, outcome measure and assessors. Again, we will fit a random effect model to synthesize the correlation coefficients. Measure of heterogeneity, the Cochrane’s Q statistics, I2 will be computed in line with Higgins and Thompson (2002). I2 values will be interpreted in line with Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Intervention as follows: 0-40% might indicate low heterogeneity, 30-60% may represent moderate heterogeneity, 50-90% may represent substantial heterogeneity, and 75-100% may indicate considerable heterogeneity (Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions. http://www.cochrane-handbook.org).

attributes.title: Community Monitoring and Technology Transfer to Prevent Deforestation: A Field Experiment in the Peruvian Amazon

q1.value: Community Monitoring and Technology Transfer to Prevent Deforestation: A Field Experiment in the Peruvian Amazon

q2.value: Jacob Kopas | Tara Slough | Johannes Urpelainen

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Continued and accelerating deforestation of the Amazon rainforest represents a grave threat. While substantial investments have been made in satellite monitoring to detect de- forestation events in the region, much of this data remains inaccessible to “first responders,” namely communities in the Amazon and, to a lesser extent, the officials tasked with prosecuting these crimes. To what extent does providing this information to the communities most threatened by deforestation allow them to respond to such threats and combat continued deforestation? Further, does facilitating contact between affected communities and government authorities promote increased legal action against offenders? The present field experiment in the Peruvian Amazon will provide indigenous communities with training, technology, and eventually weekly updated data detected by satellite monitoring on threats to their land. A second treatment arm provides resources for these communities to send a representative to share concerns and information with state environmental prosecutors. We measure a rich set of outcomes using satellite data, an original endline survey, and administrative data on cases prosecuted to assess the impacts of the community monitoring program. This study is poised to make important contributions to both theoretical and policy literature on the governance of common pool resources. First, monitoring of common pool resources by stakeholders has long been considered an important factor in improving governance outcomes (Ostrom 1990). Specifically in the case of forest preservation, the involvement of local communities in the administration and monitoring of forest resources has been widely debated. However, despite increased attention to and funding of community led projects through international aid and REDD+ grants, existing studies on relative effectiveness of community participation are severely limited by observational methodology that cannot measure an unbiased causal effect (Macura, Secco, and Pullin, 2015). This will be one of the first studies with a randomized treatment assignment that can obtain unbiased measurement of community monitoring in the Amazon region of South America, one of the largest and most important forest resources for mitigating global climate change and preserving biodiversity. Secondly, we hope to contribute to existing literature by providing evidence on diverse causal mechanisms that could allow communities to better manage forest resources through monitoring, either through increased organizational capacity, reinforcing of prescriptive norms, or intervention by national authorities.

q16.value: Main Hypotheses, Satellite Data Hypothesis 1. Main Effect of Monitoring: Relative to the control group, community monitoring (both treatment arms) reduces deforestation events and area. This negative effect of community monitoring (both arms) should present heterogeneity due to seasonality, and thus during the dry season (approximately November- April) marginal effects will be greater than during the rainy season (approximately May-October). Hypothesis 2. Marginal Effect of State Engagement: Relative to community monitoring only, the combination of community monitoring and information sharing with national authorities reduces deforestation events and area. Hypothesized Spillovers, Satellite Data Hypothesis 3. Displacement of Deforestation: Relative to the control group, community monitoring (both arms) increases deforestation events and area within a buffer zone outside the monitored communities. Main Hypotheses, Administrative Data Outcomes Hypothesis 4. Community Governance: Relative to members of control group communities, members of monitoring (both arms) community records will reflect more frequent meetings and higher attendance at meetings of the community council and the community assembly. Endline Survey Outcomes: Mechanisms Hypothesis 5. Awareness of Deforestation: Relative to members of control group communities, members of monitoring (both arms) communities manifest greater awareness of the incidence of deforestation in communal lands. Hypothesis 6. Satisfaction with Forest Conservation and Community Governance: Relative to members of control group communities, members of monitoring (both arms) communities report greater satisfaction with the current state of communal forest resources and the performance of community government. Hypothesis 7. Norm Diffusion: Relative to members of monitoring-only communities, members of monitoring and state engagement communities report higher conformity of prescriptive norms to preserve communal forest resources and cooperation norms manifested in higher levels of coordination in a set of lab games.

q17.value: Our primary intervention is an offer for a community to participate in a monitoring program of the community’s collective forests. The monitoring program itself provides communities with monitoring technology (GPS smartphones), organizational support, and using weekly updated satellite imagery. Communities will then use the program to identify threats to community forests and take action to prevent or mitigate deforestation through community government or by informing national officials. This intervention is an extension of a preexisting program that has already been successfully implemented in several indigenous communities in the Ucayali Department. This study will also implement a secondary intervention in half of the treated communities. This alternative treatment arm will include an offer of funds to a community to bring leaders and the monitoring team to the department capital (Iquitos). There, community representatives will advocate for state intervention before the regional office of the national environmental prosecutor (Fiscalía Nacional del Medio Ambiente). This intervention will also include an offer of funds to the environmental prosecutor office to travel to the community and collect evidence. The primary outcome indicator for this study will be the relative rate of deforestation in indigenous community territory. We will measure this outcome through Landsat satellite data provided by the University of Maryland Global Land Analysis and Discovery (GLAD) lab, and processed through the Alertas Tempranas (early warnings) system managed by Geobosques, a department within the Peruvian Ministry of the Environment. This study will also measure the impact of the intervention on community government and perceptions of community members through an endline survey and by accessing community government records.

q19.value: 73 Indigenous communities in the Napo and Amazon River Basins (Loreto, Peru).

attributes.title: Top-Down Effects of Labels in Object Recognition: A replication of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015)
attributes.description: We report a replication of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015).

q1.value: Top-Down Effects of Labels in Object Recognition: A replication of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015)

q2.value: Joshua de Leeuw, Jan Andrews, Wesley Olstad, Lori Barney, Yijing Chen, Eden Forbes, Connor McShaffrey, Rebecca Peng, Ryan  Cherry, Allison Wan, Lingxiu Zhang, Benjamin Haffey, Nicole Leopold, Xinyue Hu, Erik Spangenberg, Polyphony Bruna, Rena Aerey Lee, Margaret Bigler, Davon Dowie, Michael Jaklitsch, Caitlin Lewis, Dylan MacDonald, Karen Nakayama, Griffin Scott-Rifer, Logan Willans

q3.value: The purpose of this experiment is to replicate the experiment and findings of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015) to test the reproducibility of the results indicating that linguistic labels provide top-down guidance by acting as categorical clues that influence early stages of visual processing. Using a sample of native English speakers, we expect that participants will be able to correctly identify an image faster if it is prompted by a linguistic label (e.g., “dog”) as opposed to an unambiguous, non-linguistic sound (e.g., barking). The identification process will be performed while the participants’ EEG data is collected, in order to test whether there is an advantage in response time (linguistic or non-linguistic) during the early stages of visual processing, or during the later stage of semantic decision making. If there is a top-down effect taking place, we expect to see larger P1 but not N400 effects for the label condition relative to the non-linguistic sound conditions as did Boutonnet and Lupyan.

q4.value:
The purpose of the following hypotheses is to express that we expect to get results that mirror and confirm those found by Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015). 

Hypothesis1 (directional): In terms of behavioral results, we expect that linguistic label cues will lead to faster recognition of images than non-linguistic sound cues.

Hypothesis2 (directional): Pictures that are cued by linguistic labels are expected to elicit greater P1 amplitudes than when the same pictures are cued by non-linguistic sounds.

Hypothesis3 (directional):  Pictures that are cued by linguistic labels are expected to elicit greater P2 amplitudes than when the same pictures are cued by non-linguistic sounds.

Hypothesis4 (directional): Incongruent trials are expected to elicit a stronger N4 than congruent trials.

Hypothesis5: The N4 will not be modulated by audio cue type (label v. sound). 

Hypothesis6 (directional): We expect earlier peak latencies of P1 to predict  faster response times.

Hypothesis7 (directional): We expected larger peak amplitudes of P1 to predict faster response times.

Hypothesis8 (directional): We expect to find earlier peak P1 latencies for label-congruent trials relative to sound-congruent trials.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Participants will be unaware of the hypotheses of the study.

question.value:
Our study design is meant to recreate the one originally implemented by Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015) as closely as possible. This is a repeated measures 2x2 factorial design. 

The first factor consists of linguistic labels or non-linguistic sounds. The second factor consists of congruent or incongruent trials. For each trial, participants will be presented with an auditory cue (linguistic label or non-linguistic sound), followed by a visual image, after a one second delay. The task is to indicate whether the auditory cue matches the visual image. Each participant will complete 500 trials. Trials will be randomized so that the auditory/visual pairing will be congruent 50% of the time and the auditory cue will be linguistic 50% of the time and non-linguistic for the other half.  

The computer program that will be used to run the experiment was made using jsPsych. The EEG net we will use in this experiment uses a high density sensory net with 128 Ag/AgCl electrodes, as opposed to the one used by Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015) which only had 64 Ag/AgCl electrodes. We are also using NetStation as the EEG preprocessing software instead of the one used in the original study.

q9.value: The audio cues presented to the participants will be randomized from two categories, linguistic and non-linguistic labels. Following this, the images presented to the participant will be randomized from two categories, congruent or incongruent to the audio cue. This randomization will be done by our computer program written in jsPsych.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

q11.value: No one has seen any of the data that has been collected in any form related to any aspect of the analysis; data collection has only been underway for one day and only two participants' data have been collected.  Due to the fact that we are replicating a pre-existing study, we do have knowledge of the procedures, data collected, patterns discovered, and conclusions reported in the original study that we are replicating.

question.value: Introductory Cognitive Science and other students at Vassar College will be recruited on a voluntary basis through experimenter acquaintances, advertising, and class visits. Participants will be compensated with candy. Participants must be at least 18 years old and be native English speakers.

q13.value: The target sample size for our study is 35 participants.

q14.value: The study is part of a research methods class with 22 students. Each student will conduct the experiment for 2 participants, which totals to 44 participants. , Based on the heuristic of Simonsohn (2015), 35  participants should be enough for adequate power to detect an effect that is 33% of the effect size reported in the original. 44 subjects allows us to meet the pedagogical needs of the course, while also allowing for potential dropouts or exclusions due to technical failures. We will use the data collected from all subjects, potentially exceeding 35.

q15.value: Data collection will end after 44 participants have been run or after 3/1/2020. The date-based stopping rule is necessary because we are conducting the study as part of a research methods class and need to meet the needs of the class schedule.

question.value:
The first manipulated variable is the auditory cue. Audio cues will be either be linguistic labels (e.g,. ‘dog’) or non-linguistic sounds (e.g., a dog’s bark). The second variable is the congruency of the audio stimulus to the visual stimulus. For example, a barking sound and an image of a dog constitutes a congruent case, but a barking sound followed by an image of a cat would be incongruent. 

For the visual stimulus, there are a total of 10 categories: cat, car, dog, frog, gun, rooster, train, cow, whistle, and motorcycle; each containing a total of 5 images.

The stimuli (audio and visual) were provided to us by Lupyan, an author of the original study. They are the same stimuli used in the original experiment. .

EEG recording

EEG activity will be recorded using a 128-channel sensor net (Electrical Geodesics Inc.) at a sampling rate of 1000 samples/s referenced to Cz. The resulting data will be amplified using a Net Amps 400 Amplifier (Electrical Geodesics Inc.). We will focus on 17 locations congruent with those used in Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015). The locations used in Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015) and their corresponding electrode numbers in our the EGI-128 system will be PO3(67), PO4(77), PO7(65), PO8(90), PO9(68), PO10(94), O1(70), O2(83) for the P1 and P2; FC1(13), FC2(112), FCz(6), C1(30), C2(105), Cz(129), CP1(37), CP2(87), CPz(55) for the N4. Vertical eye movements and eye blinks will be monitored using two electrodes above and one below each eye. An additional pair of electrodes located on the outer side of each eye will be used to monitor horizontal eye movements. Impedances for all of these electrodes will be kept below 50 kΩ prior to data collection. Netstation 5.4 waveform tools will be used to process the EEG data offline, first by applying a high pass filter at 0.1 Hz and a low pass filter at 30 Hz. Data will be segmented into 1100 ms segments starting 100 ms prior to and ending 1000 ms after target stimulus onset. An artifact detection function will be included in the Netstation program to remove epochs with activity exceeding ±75µV as was done in Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015). Epochs with more than 20 bad channels will also be excluded. In good epochs the Netstation bad channel replacement tool will be applied to the EEG data which will be re-referenced using an average reference and baseline corrected to the 100 ms prior to stimulus onset. These processing steps are similar to those used by Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015) with some minor differences due to the use of a different EEG system.


Behavioral Data Recording

We will measure response time and accuracy for the match/mismatch judgments.

For the behavioral measures, mean correct response times will be determined for the four conditions.

For the analyses of averaged ERP data (see analysis section below), mean amplitudes will be measured from the regions of interest (see analysis section below) and time windows from the original study (70-125 ms for P1, 190-230 ms for P2, and 300-500 ms for N4).  

For the single-trial cases, to improve the signal to noise ratio, the electrodes from two regions of interest for P1 (in the areas mentioned earlier) are collapsed into an “optimized” electrode from linear derivations of the original electrodes. This optimized signal from the 65-130 ms post stimulus onset will be submitted to a peak-finding algorithm (based on the findpeaks function in MATLAB) along a series of five 13 ms sliding windows to return peak location and amplitude for each trial.

Our goal for all analyses is to faithfully replicate the analyses of the original study. Here we report the analysis models as we understand them at the time of registration. We are currently awaiting the analysis code from the original study, which we expect to receive from the authors. This code may cause some minor revisions in this plan.

Behavioral analysis
We will use linear-mixed effects models to predict reaction times from the interaction of cue type (label or sound) and congruence (whether the cue matches the image), with random slopes for cue type and congruence by participant. The critical test for H1 is the presence of a main effect of cue type. The original study also found a main effect of congruency, with match trials being faster than mismatch trials. We will test for this effect, but it is not critical to the core hypotheses of the study.

Effect of cues on amplitudes
For the ERP data, we will use linear-mixed effects model to predict mean amplitude from the interaction of cue type, congruence, and laterality (left or right parieto-occipital region of interest where electrodes are placed), with random slopes for cue type, congruence, and laterality, all by participant. This is used to analyze the P1 and P2. For the N4, there is a single region of interest and so the laterality factor is removed from the model. The critical test for H2 is whether there is a main effect of cue type on P1 mean amplitude. The critical test for H3 is whether there is a main effect of cue type on P2 mean amplitude. The critical test for H4 is whether there is a main effect of congruence on N4 mean amplitude. The critical test for H5 is the lack of an effect of cue type on the N4. 

We will also analyze the data on a single trial level using mixed effect models to correlate the amplitude and latency of P1 with the participant’s reaction time for each individual trial. The model is a linear mixed-effects model to predict single-trial peak latencies and amplitudes with random slopes of cue type and congruence by participant and item category. The critical test for H6 is whether there is a main effect of latency on RT. The critical test for H7 is whether there is a main effect of amplitude on RT.

We will also use a mixed-effects model to predict whether a trial was congruent from the interaction of single-trial peak latency, amplitude, and cue type with random slopes from cue type by participant and by item category (e.g., dog, car, etc.) The critical test for H8 is whether there is an interaction between cue type and P1 latency.  

Analyses will be conducted in R with the lme4 package.

q20.value: The behavioral data, accuracy and reaction time (calculated as the time elapsed between target picture onset and participant response), do not require any extra transforming or recoding.

q21.value: We will use the standard p < 0.05 criterion for determining statistical significance for both the behavioral and amplitude measures. We will use one-tailed p values in the expected direction of the hypothesis (matching the direction found in the original study).

q22.value: Trials where participants made an incorrect judgement on the congruency of the cue with the target image will be automatically excluded. Epochs with activity exceeding ± 75 microvolts will also be excluded as will epochs with more than 20 bad channels.

q23.value: Trials with incomplete or missing data will be excluded and noted in the paper.

q24.value: If we fail to replicate the original results using the exact time windows reported in the original study, we will conduct a reanalysis of the data using the procedure for selecting time windows described in the original paper. This involves taking a grand average across conditions (blinding the researchers to condition-specific ERP information) and selecting time windows based on the grand average waveform. If the time windows we identify from the grand average data are different than those reported in the original paper, we will reanalyze the data using the new time windows to see if there is evidence for the effects when we replicate the procedure of the original study.

q25.value:
Boutonnet, B., & Lupyan, G. (2015). Words Jump-Start Vision: A label advantage in object recognition. Journal of Neuroscience, 35(25), 9329-9335.

Simonsohn, U. (2015). Small telescopes: Detectability and the evaluation of replication results. Psychological Science, 26(5), 559-569.

registration_responses.q1: Top-Down Effects of Labels in Object Recognition: A replication of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015)
registration_responses.q2: Joshua de Leeuw, Jan Andrews, Wesley Olstad, Lori Barney, Yijing Chen, Eden Forbes, Connor McShaffrey, Rebecca Peng, Ryan  Cherry, Allison Wan, Lingxiu Zhang, Benjamin Haffey, Nicole Leopold, Xinyue Hu, Erik Spangenberg, Polyphony Bruna, Rena Aerey Lee, Margaret Bigler, Davon Dowie, Michael Jaklitsch, Caitlin Lewis, Dylan MacDonald, Karen Nakayama, Griffin Scott-Rifer, Logan Willans
registration_responses.q3: The purpose of this experiment is to replicate the experiment and findings of Boutonnet and Lupyan (2015) to test the reproducibility of the results indicating that linguistic labels provide top-down guidance by acting as categorical clues that influence early stages of visual processing. Using a sample of native English speakers, we expect that participants will be able to correctly identify an image faster if it is prompted by a linguistic label (e.g., “dog”) as opposed to an unambiguous, non-linguistic sound (e.g., barking). The identification process will be performed while the participants’ EEG data is collected, in order to test whether there is an advantage in response time (linguistic or non-linguistic) during the early stages of visual processing, or during the later stage of semantic decision making. If there is a top-down effect taking place, we expect to see larger P1 but not N400 effects for the label condition relative to the non-linguistic sound conditions as did Boutonnet and Lupyan.
registration_responses.q4:
The purpose of the following hypotheses is to express that we expect to get results that mirror and confirm those found by Boutonnet & Lupyan (2015). 

Hypothesis1 (directional): In terms of behavioral results, we expect that linguistic label cues will lead to faster recognition of images than non-linguistic sound cues.

Hypothesis2 (directional): Pictures that are cued by linguistic labels are expected to elicit greater P1 amplitudes than when the same pictures are cued by non-linguistic sounds.

Hypothesis3 (directional):  Pictures that are cued by linguistic labels are expected to elicit greater P2 amplitudes than when the same pictures are cued by non-linguistic sounds.

Hypothesis4 (directional): Incongruent trials are expected to elicit a stronger N4 than congruent trials.

Hypothesis5: The N4 will not be modulated by audio cue type (label v. sound). 

Hypothesis6 (directional): We expect earlier peak latencies of P1 to predict  faster response times.

Hypothesis7 (directional): We expected larger peak amplitudes of P1 to predict faster response times.

Hypothesis8 (directional): We expect to find earlier peak P1 latencies for label-congruent trials relative to sound-congruent trials.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We will collect data from 450 participants via MTurk— deviations from this number are due to the MTurk service and outside of our control

analyses.value: A mixed effects model using Audience  (Novice, Peer, Expert), as a fixed effect with random intercepts for subjects and items and by-subject random slopes for the effect of condition.

outliers.value: Participants who fail at least 1 of 2 initial check questions will not be allowed to continue. Those who give a 1 or 2 rating to the Excellent training item or give a 6 or 7 rating to the Poor training item will be excluded from the final analysis. Participants who fail to remember the assigned audience will also be excluded.

attributes.title: Risk factors for injuries in runners; A systematic review and meta-analyses of foot strike technique and its classification at impact.
attributes.description: A systematic review of studies investigating the relationship between foot strike technique (foot strike pattern, foot contact angles and strike index) and running-related injuries

summary.value:
This systematic review is a narrative review of the relationship between foot strike technique and running-related injuries. Foot strike technique will be explored through foot strike pattern, foot contact angles and strike index. Secondary to investigating if a relationship exists between foot strike technique and injury, the review will also explore the effect of modifying foot strike technique and it's effect on altering the risk of running-related injuries.

Databases (MEDLINE, Pubmed, Sports Discus, Scopus, Web of Science) will be searched between June and August 2019 to identify studies investigating foot strike technique and running related injuries between January 1960 and August 2019. Search terms will include "running" OR "runners" AND "injury" OR "injuries" AND "rearfoot" OR "rear-foot" OR "midfoot" OR "mid-foot" OR "forefoot" OR "fore-foot" OR "foot contact angle" OR "foot angle" OR "foot strike pattern" OR "foot strike angle" OR "foot impact angle" OR "strike index". Secondary to this, another search will be performed with the above terms in addition to "intervention" OR "biofeedback" OR "alter" OR "modify" OR "change" OR "gait re-training" OR "gait re-education".
Inclusion criteria will include studies which have researched a running population (novice, recreational, military and collegiate), studies which have looked at foot strike technique (foot strike pattern, foot contact angle and strike index) during running, studies which have explored running related injuries and how foot strike technique may affect injuries, studies which compared injured subjects to controls, studies written in the English language and studies from fully published articles. Exclusion criteria included studies that were not exclusively running populations, studies which examined upper limb injuries, studies not written in the English language, studies published as conference proceedings or abstracts, studies that are opinion articles.

Study characteristics (study type, subjects, age, sex, demographics), methods, statistics and results will be extracted and synthesized where possible. Given the diversity of methodologies in this area, a narrative review will be completed.

Secondary to investigating if a relationship exists between foot strike technique and injury, the review will also explore the effect of modifying foot strike technique and it's effect on altering the risk of running-related injuries.

Databases (MEDLINE, Pubmed, Sports Discus, Scopus, Web of Science) will be searched between June and August 2019 to identify studies investigating foot strike technique and running related injuries between January 1960 and August 2019. Search terms will include "running" OR "runners" AND "injury" OR "injuries" AND "rearfoot" OR "rear-foot" OR "midfoot" OR "mid-foot" OR "forefoot" OR "fore-foot" OR "foot contact angle" OR "foot angle" OR "foot strike pattern" OR "foot strike angle" OR "foot impact angle" OR "strike index". Secondary to this, another search will be performed with the above terms in addition to "intervention" OR "biofeedback" OR "alter" OR "modify" OR "change" OR "gait re-training" OR "gait re-education".
Inclusion criteria will include studies which have researched a running population (novice, recreational, military and collegiate), studies which have looked at foot strike technique (foot strike pattern, foot contact angle and strike index) during running, studies which have explored running related injuries and how foot strike technique may affect injuries, studies which compared injured subjects to controls, studies written in the English language and studies from fully published articles. Exclusion criteria included studies that were not exclusively running populations, studies which examined upper limb injuries, studies not written in the English language, studies published as conference proceedings or abstracts, studies that are opinion articles.

Study characteristics (study type, subjects, age, sex, demographics), methods, statistics and results will be extracted and synthesized where possible. Given the diversity of methodologies in this area, a narrative review will be completed.

summary.value:
In a previous study, we found that participants rated a Chinese applicant as more worthy or deserving of an Asian scholarship than both the Indian or Filipino applicants. (See pre-registration for the previous study: https://osf.io/nwzht/?view_only=c4cc021073d545ceb68a8a93bd601a7a). Additionally, the Chinese applicant was rated as having a stronger Asian identity and imagined to be more prototypically Asian looking than both the Indian and Filipino applicants. These findings support the hypothesis that East Asians, or Chinese individuals, are perceived as more representative of the overall Asian racial group than South Asians (e.g., Indian individuals), and Southeast Asians (e.g., Filipino individuals). 

In this follow-up study, we are testing the same hypothesis: whether people mentally represent prototypical “Asians” as East Asian (i.e. Chinese individuals) rather than as South Asian (i.e. Indian individuals) or Southeast Asian (i.e. Filipino individuals). However, we aim to more directly examine the proposed mechanism by showing that this effect appears when participants are asked to evaluate applicants in terms of how prototypically Asian the applicants are (or how well they “fit” the definition of what it means to be Asian) but does not emerge for a neutral/general type of evaluation. 

Please see attached pdf file for complete pre-registration of this study.

registration_responses.summary:
In a previous study, we found that participants rated a Chinese applicant as more worthy or deserving of an Asian scholarship than both the Indian or Filipino applicants. (See pre-registration for the previous study: https://osf.io/nwzht/?view_only=c4cc021073d545ceb68a8a93bd601a7a). Additionally, the Chinese applicant was rated as having a stronger Asian identity and imagined to be more prototypically Asian looking than both the Indian and Filipino applicants. These findings support the hypothesis that East Asians, or Chinese individuals, are perceived as more representative of the overall Asian racial group than South Asians (e.g., Indian individuals), and Southeast Asians (e.g., Filipino individuals). 

In this follow-up study, we are testing the same hypothesis: whether people mentally represent prototypical “Asians” as East Asian (i.e. Chinese individuals) rather than as South Asian (i.e. Indian individuals) or Southeast Asian (i.e. Filipino individuals). However, we aim to more directly examine the proposed mechanism by showing that this effect appears when participants are asked to evaluate applicants in terms of how prototypically Asian the applicants are (or how well they “fit” the definition of what it means to be Asian) but does not emerge for a neutral/general type of evaluation. 

Please see attached pdf file for complete pre-registration of this study.
